I hear your company takes on capable fighters. I can handle myself in a scrap - interested?
You look useful. We pay fair coin for good work, and dead men don't collect. Fall in with the lads and keep your blade sharp.
Captain, I've been riding with the company long enough. Time we settled accounts.
You've earned your share and then some. Take your coin now and walk free, or stick around another year - I'll sweeten the pot. Your call.
I'll take my cut now. It's been good riding with you.
Coin's good, company's better. I'll stick around for that bonus.
Let me think on it. I'll find you when I've decided.
Fair winds, fighter. You've done right by the company. If you ever need work again, you know where to find us.
Smart choice. The lads will be glad to have you. Your bonus is guaranteed when the year's up. Now let's find some trouble.
Captain, the year's up. What's the score?
Another year done, and you're still breathing. Take your gold and go free, or sign on for another round - same deal as before. What'll it be?
I'll take my share. Time to see what else is out there.
The road's been good to me here. I'm in for another year.
Your coin's counted and your horse is yours. Good luck out there - and if you hear of any good contracts, send word.
Good man. The company's better for having you. Same terms, same coin - let's get back to work.
I've had my rest. Ready to get back to work, captain.
Good timing. We've got work lined up and could use another blade. Fall in with the lads.
Captain, I need to break contract early. Something's come up.
Contract's done then. No hard feelings - everyone's got their reasons. Don't expect a warm welcome if you come crawling back soon, though.
Your {UNIT_NAME} has served you well these many months. What of your men? They may return to the ranks, or... if they wish to follow you into the unknown, I shall not stop them.
My men have chosen to march with me, my lord. We've bled together - that bond does not break so easily.
Let them return to the army. They signed on to serve the kingdom, not one man.
So be it. Your {COUNT} soldiers have decided to stay with you rather than re-enlist. I've had the quartermaster set aside provisions for your journey. Fare well, soldier.
Your lads have been asking around. Word is they'd rather follow you than draw army pay. Your call, fighter.
Tell them to pack their gear. We ride together.
They're good fighters. The company needs them more than I do.
Ha! Loyal to the end, that lot. Your {COUNT} have decided to stay with you instead of signing back on. Here's some grain for the road - you'll need it. Don't be a stranger.

Your equipment gleams, your stance is flawless. The captain gives a curt nod of approval. 'This is the standard,' he tells the others. Your fellow soldiers take note, and the officers remember your discipline.
Meet the basic requirements
You're presentable enough. The captain moves on without comment. You've met expectationsâ€”nothing more, nothing less.
You're not ready

Your equipment is dirty, your bearing slovenly. The captain's face darkens. 'Five laps around camp with full pack,' he orders. 'Then report to the quartermaster for extra duties.' The other soldiers avoid your gaze as you fall out of formation.
Green Recruit

At morning muster, a terrified-looking recruit stands trembling in the front rank. He's barely holding his spear correctly, and his eyes dart nervously at every sound. The veterans are already snickering. As a seasoned soldier, you could step inâ€”or let him learn the hard way.
Take him aside and show him the ropes

You pull the recruit aside after muster and spend time correcting his grip, his stance, his bearing. He's grateful and eager to learn. The officers notice your leadership, and your fellow soldiers respect your patience. The recruit will remember this kindness.
Let him figure it out
You keep to yourself. The recruit muddles through as best he can. Some soldiers grumble that veterans should help new blood, but you've got your own concerns.
Give him the traditional welcome

You join the other soldiers in putting the recruit through a series of 'tests'â€”carrying extra gear, fetching water, standing extra watches. He's miserable but keeps his mouth shut. The soldiers accept you as one of them, though the officers frown at the hazing.
Dice Game

A group of soldiers have gathered around a blanket, shaking dice and passing coins. The game is technically against regulations, but the officers are occupied elsewhere. One of the soldiers notices you watching and waves you over. 'Got coin to lose, friend?'
Join the game

You sit down and toss your coin onto the blanket. The dice roll, fortunes shift, and when the game breaks up an hour later, you're up fifty denars. The other soldiers clap you on the backâ€”you're one of them now.
Watch without playing

You watch the game, learning the players' tells and tricks without risking your coin. The soldiers don't mindâ€”at least you're not running to the officers. You pick up some useful knowledge about reading people.
Report the game to the officers

You walk straight to the officers' tent and report the illegal gambling. They break up the game immediately. The officers appreciate your adherence to regulations, but your fellow soldiers won't forget your betrayal. The camp feels colder afterward.
Tales by the Fire

Soldiers gather around the evening fire, and the talk turns to stories. The veterans begin sharing tales of past campaigns and legendary warriors. Eyes turn to you expectantlyâ€”you've seen your share of action.
Share your battle experiences

You recount the battle at the river crossingâ€”the chaos, the fear, the moment the line nearly broke but held. The soldiers listen intently, nodding at the familiar details. When you finish, there's a moment of respectful silence. You've earned their respect.
Tell the old legends

You reach back to the ancient talesâ€”heroes and monsters, betrayals and triumphs. Your words paint pictures in the fire-lit darkness. The younger soldiers are captivated, and even the veterans lean in. The stories remind everyone what they're fighting for.
Listen to the veterans
You sit back and let the veterans talk. Their stories contain hard-earned wisdom about tactics, terrain, and survival. You learn more from listening than you would from speaking.
Hungry Soldiers

The rations are running low again. As you collect your meager portion, you notice some soldiers getting even lessâ€”their eyes hollow with hunger. You have a few days' worth of food stashed away from previous campaigns. You could share it, but that's your safety margin if things get worse.
Share your extra rations

You quietly distribute your stash among the hungriest soldiers. They're grateful beyond words. Your belly might be empty tonight, but you've earned genuine loyalty from your comrades. Even the officers hear about your generosity.
Lead a foraging party

You volunteer to lead a small group into the countryside to forage. Hours of searching yield edible plants, some game, and a forgotten granary. You return with enough food to ease the shortage. The company is grateful, and your reputation as someone who takes action grows.
Keep your supplies hidden

You keep your stash secret and eat when others aren't watching. You're well-fed, but some soldiers notice your relative health compared to their hunger. Suspicious looks and cold shoulders follow. Trust is harder to earn than food.
Camp Brawl

A fight breaks out near the supply wagonsâ€”two soldiers, one from your unit and one from another company, trading vicious blows. A crowd forms, shouting encouragement. The officers haven't noticed yet, but they will soon. Your fellow soldier is losing.
Break up the fight

You push through the crowd and step between them, taking a stray punch for your trouble. 'Enough!' you bark. Your authority and presence shock them into stopping. The officers arrive moments later and thank you for preventing a serious incident. Both brawlers are assigned punishment detail.
Back your comrade

You wade in swinging. Together, you and your fellow soldier pummel the other man until he stays down. The crowd roars approvalâ€”but here come the officers. You all end up in chains for the night, but your comrades know you've got their backs. That counts for something.
Run for an officer

You sprint to the officers' tent and return with a captain. He breaks up the fight immediately and hauls both brawlers off for punishment. The officers appreciate your quick thinking, but your fellow soldiers eye you with distrust. Nobody likes a snitch.
Invitation to Hunt
{LORD_NAME} is organizing a hunting party. A messenger approaches you with an invitation. The Lord's hunts are known for good sport and fine company - though they can be tiring affairs.
"I am honored, my Lord. I shall attend."
You spend the day riding with {LORD_NAME}'s party. The hunt is successful - deer are brought down, and the mood is jovial. As the party returns, {LORD_NAME} offers you your share.
"I am grateful for the honor, but duty keeps me at camp."
The messenger nods and departs. Perhaps another time.
Evening Dice Game
{COMRADE_NAME} waves you over to a group gathered around a small fire. "Come on, {PLAYER_RANK}! We need fresh gold in the pot." The dice game looks lively, and you could use some relaxation.
"Deal me in - small stakes only."
Lady luck favors you tonight. You walk away with your stake doubled and a few new friends.
"I'm feeling lucky. High stakes."
The dice fly, the gold flows. You take the pot with a winning streak that has the whole camp talking.
"Not tonight. I need my rest."
You retire to your tent. The sounds of laughter and curses drift through the night.
Training Opportunity

{SERGEANT_NAME} approaches during training. "You show promise, soldier. I could work with you after the regular session - push you harder than the rest. It'll be exhausting, but you'll improve faster."
"I'm ready for whatever you can teach me, Sergeant."
The additional training is brutal, but effective. Your muscles ache, but your blade moves faster.
"I appreciate the offer, but I need to pace myself."
{SERGEANT_NAME} shrugs. "Your choice. The offer stands." You continue with the standard regimen.
Special Scouting Assignment
{SERGEANT_NAME} pulls you aside. "I need someone reliable for a longer patrol. Two days out, mapping the terrain ahead. It's harder work, but I'll make sure you're compensated."
"Consider it done. I'll have a full report for you."
You ride out at dawn and return two days later with detailed reports. {SERGEANT_NAME} nods with approval and hands you a pouch of coins.
"I'm not in condition for extended patrol right now."
{SERGEANT_NAME} frowns slightly but accepts your answer. Someone else will take the assignment.
Medical Emergency
A commotion breaks out near the medical tent. One of the wounded has taken a turn for the worse - fever and infection. The other medics look to you. "What do we do? The surgeon isn't here!"
"Get me clean water and fresh bandages. I'll handle this."
You work through the night, applying poultices and monitoring the soldier's condition. By dawn, the fever breaks. Word spreads of your skill.
"We need the surgeon. Someone ride to find him - I'll stabilize the patient."
You keep the soldier stable until the surgeon arrives. A prudent choice - the surgeon handles the complication expertly.
Merchant's Proposition

A traveling merchant approaches with a wagon of surplus goods. "I've got quality supplies here - arrows, blankets, preserved meat. I can give you a good price, but I need to move quickly. The captain doesn't need to know the details..."
"I'll need to clear any purchase through proper channels."
The merchant grumbles but agrees to wait. You get authorization, and the company gains quality supplies through legitimate means.
"Show me what you've got. We can work something out."
You skim a little off the top while getting the company a good deal. Risky, but profitable.
"Something seems off here. I should report this."
You alert the captain. The merchant's goods turn out to be stolen from a nearby village. Your vigilance is noted.
Supply Run
The wagons are light and the men are counting days between towns. You can make a run to secure supplies â€” properly, quietly, or harshly.
Do it properly: pay a fair price, record it cleanly.
You spend coin and time, but the wagons come back heavier and the ledger stays clean. The quartermaster gives you a rare, approving nod.
Make it work: buy cheap, skim a little, keep everyone fed.
You get the supplies. You also get paid. For now, nobody asks how the numbers work out.
Ration hard: stretch what we have and keep the wagons moving.
You tighten belts and enforce rationing. The men grumble, but the supplies last longer.
Audit Pressure
A clerk is sniffing around the ledgers, asking careful questions. If anything is wrong, they'll find it. You can face it, bury it, or buy time.
Cooperate: fix what you can and take the hit.
You swallow pride and clean up the mess. It costs you standing, but the investigation cools â€” for now.
Burn the paper trail: make the problem disappear.
The ledger pages curl to ash. The questions stop. But you've crossed a line that doesn't uncross.
Buy time: pay a quiet bribe and keep things moving.
Coin changes hands. The clerk loses interest. You gain a few weeks of breathing room.
A Favor Asked

{COMRADE_NAME} pulls you aside with a troubled look. "I need to ask a favor. My family... they've fallen behind on their debts. I need coin, and quickly. Could you lend me something? I swear I'll repay you when I can."
"Take what you need, friend. We look after our own."
{COMRADE_NAME}'s face floods with relief. "You're a good soldier, {PLAYER_NAME}. I won't forget this." He takes the coin and hurries off to send it to his family.
"I can spare a little. It's not much, but take it."
{COMRADE_NAME} nods gratefully. "Every bit helps. Thank you, {PLAYER_NAME}." He pockets the coins with a small smile.
"I can't afford to give away my coin. I'm sorry."
{COMRADE_NAME}'s expression hardens slightly, but he nods. "I understand. Times are hard for everyone." He walks away without another word.
A Debt Repaid

{COMRADE_NAME} approaches with a grin and a pouch of coins. "I told you I'd repay you, didn't I? My sister sold some of the family land - we're back on our feet. Here's what I owe, and a little extra for your trust."
"I'm glad things worked out. Thank you."
You pocket the coins with a nod. {COMRADE_NAME} claps you on the shoulder. "If you ever need anything, just ask." A bond has been strengthened.
"Keep it. Consider it a gift between comrades."
{COMRADE_NAME} stares at you in surprise, then breaks into a broad smile. "You're one of the good ones, {PLAYER_NAME}. I'll remember this." Your reputation in the company soars.
A Small Thanks
{COMRADE_NAME} finds you during a rest break and hands you a small bundle. "It's not much, but I found this while foraging. Thought you might want it, after what you did for me."
"Thank you. It means a lot."
You unwrap the bundle to find a few useful supplies. Small gestures, but they build trust within the company.
"Keep it. You don't owe me anything."
{COMRADE_NAME} insists once, then nods, embarrassed but grateful. "Still... thank you." The gesture seems to matter more than the coin.
Your legs ache from the march and your eyes burn from too many watches. A soldier learns to grab sleep wherever he can find it.
Find a shady spot and steal what rest you can.
You wedge yourself between supply crates, cloak bundled as a pillow. The camp noise fades. When you stir, the shadows have moved but you feel lighter.
Rest near the fire with the other soldiers.
You doze at the fire's edge, half-listening to the men's talk. Not deep sleep, but the company keeps the darker thoughts at bay.
Push through. Sleep is for the garrison.
You shake off the weariness. The campaign waits for no man's comfort.
Extended Rest
You need real sleep, not just a nap. A full night's rest would do wonders, but you'd be unavailable for a while.
Find your bedroll and get proper sleep.
You sleep deeply and wake feeling like a new man. Your body thanks you for the rest.
I can sleep when I'm dead.
You push through the exhaustion. Sleep can wait.
Seek Treatment
The surgeon's tent. Time to deal with your wounds properly. It'll cost coin, but proper care prevents worse problems.
Pay for proper treatment. (30 gold)
The surgeon cleans and binds your wounds with practiced hands. It stings like hell, but you'll heal clean.
Just the basics - bandages and salve. (10 gold)
Basic supplies change hands. It's not fancy, but it helps.
I'll manage on my own.
You leave the surgeon's tent. Time and luck will have to do the work.
Weapon Drill
Practice forms with the training posts. Basic work, but it builds muscle memory.
Work through the basic forms.
Swing, block, thrust, recover. You run through the forms until your arms burn. It's honest work.
Not now.
The training posts will be there tomorrow.
Sparring Match
The drill ground is busy. A few soldiers are working through forms, but the real learning happens when blades cross. {SOLDIER_NAME} catches your eye and tilts his head toward the practice ring.
Accept the invitation. Keep it friendly.
Wooden blades crack together as you circle, testing each other's guards. Neither of you holds back, but nobody's trying to prove anything. You're both better for it.
Make it count. Fight like you mean it.

This one draws blood. You go at each other like there's a real grudge, and the watching soldiers fall quiet. When it's done, you're both breathing hard and sporting fresh bruises. Word will spread about this bout.
Not today. Shake your head and move on.
{SOLDIER_NAME} shrugs and finds another partner. No shame in knowing when to save your strength.
Endurance Training
Run the camp perimeter until your lungs burn. Soldiers live and die by their stamina.
Run laps around the camp.
You run until your chest heaves and your legs scream for mercy. Each lap makes you harder to kill.
Save my energy.
You decide to conserve your strength for when it matters.
Study Tactics
Borrow a map, think about formations. Wars are won by those who think before they fight.
Study the maps and think about what you've seen.
You pore over old battle maps, considering terrain, formation, and timing. The patterns of war become clearer.
Maps can wait.
You set aside the scrolls. Practice beats theory anyway.
Practice Medicine
Offer to help the surgeon with simple cases. Field medicine isn't pretty, but it saves lives.
Help the surgeon with patients.
You spend hours helping with wounds and illnesses. The surgeon grunts approval at your work. The patients appreciate a steady hand.
Not today.
The surgeon has other helpers. Your hands stay clean.
Train the Men
Take recruits through drills. They'll learn from your experience - assuming you don't break them first.
Take charge of training drills.
You put the recruits through their paces. They curse your name, but they'll fight better for it. The officers nod approvingly.
Let someone else handle it.
Training is someone else's responsibility today.
Combat Drill
Request extra drill time with the sergeant. Hard work, but it sharpens your equipped weapon skills.
Practice with your equipped weapon.
The sergeant works you hard, focusing on the weapon you carry. Your movements become more fluid, more deadly.
Maybe later.
The drill grounds can wait.
Weapon Specialization
Focus your training on the weapon you use most. Specialists kill faster than generalists.
Focus on mastering your main weapon.
Hours of focused practice. Your hands know this weapon like an extension of your body now.
I prefer variety.
Specialization can wait. Flexibility has its merits.
Lead Drill Practice
Lead drill practice for younger soldiers. Teaching reinforces your own skills while building your reputation.
Take charge of junior soldiers' training.
You command the drill with authority. The young soldiers respond to your orders crisply. Officers watching from the sidelines look impressed.
Let the sergeants handle it.
Training others isn't your job today.
Join the Men
Sit by their fire, share stories. Good for morale - theirs and yours.
Sit with the soldiers at their fire.
You share warmth and stories with your comrades. They appreciate an equal. The officers might not approve, but camaraderie is earned, not assigned.
Keep my distance.
You stay apart. Sometimes a soldier needs his own company.
Join the Drinking
Someone's opened a cask. Join in? Drinking builds bonds but attracts attention.
Have a few drinks with the lads.
You share drink and laughter. The night blurs pleasantly. Tomorrow's headache will be worth tonight's camaraderie.
Drink deep and let the night take you.
You drink until the stars spin. They'll talk about this night. Whether that's good or bad remains to be seen.
I'll pass.
You decline the drink. Clear heads have their value.
Seek the Officers
Linger near the command tent, look useful. Ambition requires visibility.
Make yourself visible to the officers.
You find reasons to be near the command tent. The officers notice. The men notice too - and they don't always approve of climbers.
Stay with my own rank.
You stay with the men. Advancement can come naturally.
Keep to Yourself
Sometimes solitude is worth more than company. Find a quiet spot away from the crowd.
Find somewhere quiet and be alone.
You find a quiet corner of camp and let your thoughts settle. The silence is a relief after the constant noise of military life.
Maybe I should be social.
You reconsider. The company of others has its merits.
Write a Letter Home
Ink, paper, and memories of another life. Someone back home might appreciate hearing from you.
Write a reassuring letter, downplaying the dangers.
You craft careful words of safety and good fortune. No need to worry those waiting for you. The courier takes your letter with the next dispatch.
Write honestly about your experiences.
The truth flows onto the page - the fear, the boredom, the moments of strange pride. It feels good to be honest, even if the words might worry them.
The words won't come today.
You set aside the paper. Another time.
Confront Your Rival
This has gone on long enough. There's someone in camp who's been making your life difficult. Time to settle it.
Confront them directly, with words.
You find your rival and say what needs saying. The tension breaks - for better or worse, the air is cleared.
Settle it with fists, away from officers.
You trade blows behind the supply wagons. Win or lose, it's done. The men respect those who handle their problems directly.
Let it go, for now.
You swallow your anger. Some battles aren't worth fighting.
Gamble (Low Stakes)
Behind the supply wagons, a circle of soldiers hunches over a blanket. Dice clatter, coins change hands. Someone spots you watching and waves you over. 'Room for one more, if your coin's good.'
Toss in your copper and play for laughs. (10 gold stake)
The bones love you tonight. You sweep a modest pot toward yourself while the others groan and call for another round. Easy money, easy company.
The dice turn cold. Your stake vanishes into other purses, but you share the groans and laughter with the rest. Cost of camaraderie.
Play carefully. Watch the odds. (10 gold stake)
You play tight, fold when the odds turn, push when they favor you. The pot's smaller, but it's yours. The others eye you with something between respect and annoyance.
Even careful play can't beat a cold run. You walk away lighter, but at least you didn't chase your losses.
'Not tonight, lads.' Keep walking.
You wave them off and move on. Your purse stays full, but you miss the camaraderie of the circle.
Gamble (High Stakes)
Real money. Real risk. The kind of game where fortunes change hands.
Put real money on the table. (50 gold stake)
Fortune favors the bold! You rake in a substantial pot. The losers eye you with new respect - or jealousy.
The dice betray you. Your stake is gone, and then some. The winners smirk as you count what's left.
Too rich for my blood.
You keep your gold in your purse. Wisdom, or cowardice? Only you know.
Side Work
Someone in camp needs labor. Pays decent - if you don't mind the sweat.
Put in extra labor for coin.
Hours of hard labor - hauling, digging, lifting. Your back aches, but your purse is heavier.
My duty is enough.
You pass on the extra work. Rest has value too.
Shady Deal
A man knows a man who has something to sell. The goods look legitimate enough, but the price is suspiciously low.
Make the deal. Don't ask questions.
Coin changes hands in shadows. You don't know where the goods came from, and you don't ask. Profit is profit.
Report the suspicious offer.
You tell the officers about the offer. They nod approvingly. The shady man disappears before anyone can question him.
Walk away.
You want no part of whatever this is. Clean hands are worth more than dirty coin.
Visit the Market
Browse what the town has to offer. Supplies, luxuries, maybe something useful.
Spend some time browsing the stalls.
You wander the market, examining wares. The variety is a pleasant change from camp rations and military issue.
No time for shopping.
Duty calls louder than commerce.
Request an Audience

The lord's banner hangs above the command tent. Guards stand watch, and officers come and go on important business. A common soldier doesn't just walk in—but your rank has earned you the right to petition, if you've something worth saying.
Remind the lord of your service. Speak of what you've done.
{LORD_NAME} hears you out, eyes sharp. When you finish, there's a pause—then a single nod. 'I know your face now, soldier. Continue to serve well.' It's not much, but from a lord, it's everything.
Humbly request an advance on wages. Debts press hard.

You explain your circumstances as briefly as you can. The lord's expression is unreadable, but he gestures to his steward. A purse of coins lands in your palm. 'See that it's repaid in service.' You're in debt now—of a different kind.
Ask for the chance to prove yourself in some special task.

The lord's eyebrow rises. Ambition, or foolishness? 'I'll remember your eagerness, soldier. When something needs doing, perhaps I'll send for you.' You've put your name forward. Now you must prove worthy of it.
Lose your nerve. This isn't the time.
You hover at the tent's edge, then turn away. The guards don't even glance at you. Better to wait for a stronger hand to play.
Volunteer for Duty
Tell the sergeant you want extra work. Initiative is noticed - for better or worse.
Volunteer for additional duties.
{NCO_NAME} nods at your offer. Extra work finds you quickly. The officers appreciate initiative. Some of the men think you're showing off.
My regular duties are enough.
You stay quiet. No need to stand out more than necessary.
Request Leave
Ask permission to visit town on your own time. Officers don't always approve, but it doesn't hurt to ask.
Request permission for leave.
Permission granted, with conditions. You have until evening. Don't make them regret it.
Request denied. The officer barely looks up. 'We march soon. Stay with the company.'
Never mind.
You decide not to ask. There will be other opportunities.
Listen to Rumors
Keep your ears open around camp. Information is currency in any army.
Drift through camp, listening to talk.
You catch fragments of conversation - troop movements, noble politics, fears and hopes. Some of it might even be true.
Rumors are for bored soldiers.
You have better things to do than gossip.
Scout the Surroundings
Take a walk beyond the camp perimeter. Know the land - it might save your life.
Walk the perimeter and beyond.
You explore the terrain around camp - paths, hiding spots, approaches. Knowledge that might matter when swords are drawn.
Stay inside the perimeter.
The camp is safe enough. No need to wander.
Check Supply Situation
Ask the quartermaster how we're doing. Good to know before things get desperate.
Inquire about the company's supplies.
The quartermaster shares the state of things - food stores, fodder, equipment. Information is power, even in small matters.
I'll find out when everyone else does.
Ignorance has its comforts. You'll know when you need to know.
Maintain Your Gear
Oil, polish, sharpen. Keep it battle-ready. A soldier's gear is his life.
Spend time maintaining your equipment.
You work methodically - cleaning rust, sharpening edges, oiling leather. Your gear is ready for whatever comes.
Good enough for now.
Your gear will survive another day. Probably.
Visit the Quartermaster
See what's available, maybe make a request. The quartermaster has what you need - for a price.
See what the quartermaster has in stock.
You browse the quartermaster's stores. Weapons, armor, supplies - all available for coin or requisition. Good to know what's possible.
I have what I need.
Your current kit will serve. No need to spend coin you don't have.
Accept a Dangerous Wager

The men are getting creative with boredom. {SOLDIER_NAME} grins at you across the fire. 'Heard you've got brass ones. Bet you twenty denars you can't...' What follows is either incredibly dangerous or incredibly stupid. Possibly both.
'You're on.' Stand up and prove it.

Your heart pounds, the men roar, and somehow—you pull it off. {SOLDIER_NAME}'s coins land in your palm while the camp erupts. They'll be telling this story for weeks. You'll be feeling it for just as long.

Pride goes before the fall. You hit the ground hard, or burn yourself, or whatever fool thing you were attempting goes wrong. The men wince. The coin goes to {SOLDIER_NAME}. Your pride goes to the mud.
'Double or nothing—but on my terms.'
You turn the challenge around, stack the odds your way. It's still risky, but calculated. When you succeed, the winnings are sweeter—and you barely limp afterward.
Even the clever approach goes wrong sometimes. You're out more coin and nursing new bruises. At least you tried to be smart about it.
'I've nothing to prove to you.' Stay seated.
You shake your head. {SOLDIER_NAME} shrugs, calls you sensible or coward depending on the drink in him. Tomorrow, nobody will remember you turned it down. Or maybe they will.
Prove Your Courage
Do something reckless to earn respect. The men respect courage - even the foolish kind.
Do something bold and reckless.
You do something brave and stupid. The men cheer. The officers groan. Your body pays the price, but your reputation doesn't.
Courage can wait.
You decide against showboating. Real courage shows in battle, not in camp stunts.
Challenge Someone
Call them out. Settle it properly, with witnesses. The old ways still matter.
Issue a formal challenge.
Steel rings, blood flows. Win or lose, you've made a statement. The officers will hear about this - as will everyone else.
Some insults aren't worth dying for.
You let it pass. The smart choice, if not the satisfying one.
The battlefield is the only home I know, my lord. I shall stay and earn that gold.
I thank you for everything, my lord. It has been an honor to serve under your banner.
You have my oath, my lord. Point me at the enemy.
Ha! That's the spirit! I knew I could count on you. Another year, then. Try not to get yourself killed.
Why would I leave now? We have enemies yet to crush. Count me in for another year.
Your offer is generous, my lord, but I must think on it. Perhaps another time.

Hold a moment... I recognize your bearing. You serve another lord, do you not? A soldier cannot serve two masters. Return to your commander, or settle your affairs with them first before approaching me.
My lord, I seek to speak with you about bearing arms in your service.
If you wish to leave my service, do it properly. Make camp and request discharge. Your final pay and discharge papers will be handled at the next muster.
My lord, if I wished to leave your service, how would I do so properly?
My lord, I have served faithfully these many months. The time has come to discuss my future.
My lord, I must ask to be released from my oath. I cannot continue.
I release you from your oath. You leave without the honors of a full term, but you are free. Go, and think carefully before you take up arms again.
You have been discharged from service without full benefits.
I see the steel in your eyes. You'll do. But know this - I expect loyalty, discipline, and courage. Here are my terms...
A soldier who seeks a new banner rather than deserting? That speaks well of your character. I welcome you to my company. These are my terms...
Speak freely. What brings a warrior to my hall?
Ha! I knew you had more fight in you. Your gold will be waiting when the year is done. Now get back to your post.
My lord, you may remember me - I served this realm before. The quiet life does not suit me. Will you have me back?
My lord, another year has passed. What becomes of me now?
It is time I sought my own path, my lord. I thank you for the opportunity.
Then this is farewell, for now. You have been a fine soldier. May the winds carry you to fortune.
You have proven yourself time and again. Take your discharge with five thousand gold and my blessing, or stay another year with a bonus to match. What say you?
I offer you my sword and my loyalty, my lord. Will you have me in your ranks?
My lord, fate has taken my commander from me. I am a soldier without a banner, but my oath to this kingdom remains. Will you take me under your command?
My lord, I currently serve another of this realm, but I believe my talents would be better suited under your banner. Would you accept my transfer?

You have served with honor, and I do not forget loyalty. Retire now and you leave with gold in your pocket, my personal letter of recommendation, and the respect of this kingdom. Or... stay another year, and I shall double your severance. The choice is yours.
Go well, soldier. You have earned your peace. Should you ever wish to return, my door remains open.
This is not a decision to make lightly. Give me time to consider, my lord.
Good to see you standing tall again. The men will be glad to have you back. Fall in with your company.
I have rested enough, my lord. My blade grows restless. I am ready to return to the front.
You have returned to active military service.
Forgive me, my lord. I spoke out of turn. I have nothing to discuss at this time.

You will march when I say march, fight when I say fight, and hold the line when all seems lost. Your term is three years. In return, you shall have daily wages and a place by the fire. Do we have an accord?
A soldier who knows his worth. Very well, I shall send word to your former commander. From this day, you march with me.
You have transferred your service to {LORD_NAME}. Your rank and experience have been preserved.
